body_html:
I'm sorry, I am unable to reproduce your problem. Please list out the full code you're running, starting from a clean slate. For example, I ran the following snippet and it succeeds. Does it work for your? If it does, what precise changes cause it to fail?

python
import tensorflow as tf
print tf.__version__
x = tf.placeholder(tf.float32, shape=[None, 128*128*3])
y_ = tf.placeholder(tf.float32, shape=[None, 128*256*3])
W = tf.Variable(tf.zeros([128*3,256*3]))
b = tf.Variable(tf.zeros([128*256*3]))
tf.Session().run(tf.global_variables_initializer())

Note that I have changed the shape of the W variable to be much smaller.
If you're using the size mentioned in your snippet earlier of [128*128*3,128*256*3] on your 8GB machine, then you will run into trouble as this tensor would require 18GB and will cause your system to thrash heavily.

body:
I'm sorry, I am unable to reproduce your problem. Please list out the full code you're running, starting from a clean slate. For example, I ran the following snippet and it succeeds. Does it work for your? If it does, what precise changes cause it to fail?

```python
python
import tensorflow as tf
print tf.__version__
x = tf.placeholder(tf.float32, shape=[None, 128*128*3])
y_ = tf.placeholder(tf.float32, shape=[None, 128*256*3])
W = tf.Variable(tf.zeros([128*3,256*3]))
b = tf.Variable(tf.zeros([128*256*3]))
tf.Session().run(tf.global_variables_initializer())
```

Note that I have changed the shape of the `W` variable to be much smaller.
If you're using the size mentioned in your snippet earlier of `[128*128*3,128*256*3]` on your 8GB machine, then you will run into trouble as this tensor would require 18GB and will cause your system to thrash heavily.
